Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: New Directions in Optical-Instrument-Driven Aeronomy at Arecibo Observatory
Award.AbstractNarration: The investigators will use the enhanced instrument cluster at Arecibo Observatory (AO) to gain new insight into the complex nature of the space-atmosphere interaction region (SAIR). The new High Frequency (HF) heating facility with the ISR (Incoherent Scatter Radar) and other instruments provides a unique opportunity to study heating-related aeronomic and plasma physics problems. This includes the rapidly-imaged observation of airglow at 557.7 nm, 630.0 nm and 427.8 nm during ionospheric "heating" campaigns to understand the role of HF-heating in generating plasma bubbles, or modulating them if already present, and to understand the role of secondary suprathermal electrons in producing airglow at different wavelengths. This research will also yield insight to the heating process, including locating ionospheric "hot-spots", yielding details of the electron collision process, elucidating the role of Langmuir and ion-acoustic waves in the strongly heated regions, and study of heating effects in Sporadic E. The latter study will include Ca+ metal-lidar observations as further defined by 555.7 nm imaging as well as ISR and HF radar results. HF heating of the ionosphere offers a unique opportunity to investigate the plasma heating process and its effects on the neutrals in a controlled (experimental) fashion. Outside of the heating campaigns, a database of 630 nm all-sky camera images from other locations will be assembled collaboratively to investigate the global context of the omnipresent ~1 hr period ionospheric waves, and associated dynamics, first identified with the AO ISR. This work will utilize other AO instruments, including the resonance and Rayleigh lidars, to investigate the role of wave coupling from lower atmospheric regions. Also, a proposed new CCD camera will allow high speed imaging to better understand HF heating effects and linking optical and radar meteors to study meteoroid aeronomy. The response of the SAIR to sudden changes in the environment caused by heating will be explored with the collaborative use of multiple instruments, thus informing numerous geophysical research areas. The multidisciplinary nature of this work will help to establish collaborations with plasma physicists, modelers, and space weather scientists. It will also advance the AO cluster capabilities with the addition of a User-Owned, Public Access (UOPA) high frame rate CCD to the current imager and help in establishing international collaborations. Students representing minorities from local universities in Puerto Rico will be encouraged to participate in observations and data analysis. They will be involved in the improvements of the optical systems including training on AO instrumentation and the application of these instruments to study aeronomy of the SAIR.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the seven-year span (included no-cost extensions) of this grant, observations using the Arecibo Observatory (AO) instrument cluster provided new insights into the complex nature of the space atmosphere interaction region (SAIR). Penn State (PSU) PIs and students together with AO staff scientists conducted optical imager, metals lidar, incoherent scatter radar (ISR), and HF (High-Frequency) radar observing campaigns that were coordinated with other AO cluster instruments and with active ionospheric modification (via high-power HF transmitters) campaigns. An additional major contribution came from the Global Positioning System Total Electron Content (GPS-TEC) database for which we developed a complete suite of open source analysis and display software which is an integral part of the PhD thesis work of grad student Ross Dinsmore. The Penn State HF radar system was deployed at AO for an ionospheric heating campaign providing, along with GPS-TEC results, the mesoscale ionospheric environment surrounding the ?deep context? aeronomic activity revealed by the ISR. Initial results have been reported in a journal article by Prof. Salih Bostan, a PhD graduate of this program. This research has also yielded radio science and aeronomic insights into the role of ionospheric heating process including crating ionospheric ?hot-spots?. Another now published study included Ca+, Na, & K metal-lidar observations by AO senior scientist Dr. Shikha Raizada, combined with ISR results that suggest a reservoir of metal ions ranging from above the tradition metal-ion sporadic-E zone near 110 km altitude to 200 km altitude. The global-scale GPS-TEC imaging initiative evolved to investigate the global context of the omnipresent ~1 hr period ionospheric waves, and associated dynamics, first identified with the AO ISR with observations continued using the Millstone Hill (MA) ISR. This work is presented in a journal article by Ross Dinsmore now in review along with a 2nd paper nearing submission and his PhD thesis. 

Intellectual Merit: The collaborative use of the AO instrument cluster has provided insight into HF heating of the ionosphere, the response of the SAIR to sudden changes in the environment caused by heating, and development of GPS-TEC ?imaging? of ionospheric processes revealing the apparent source of global-scale, continuous ~1 hr period LSTIDs (Large-Scale Traveling Ionospheric Disturbances) to be impulsive Joule Heating events occurring around the auroral oval. Additionally lidar/radar observations have strongly suggested a reservoir of meteoroid-derived metal ions in the 110-200 km region of the ionosphere.

 

Broader Impacts: The unique AO instrument cluster, including ?deep context? lidar and ISR, and the Penn State HF radar have been used observationally and in active experiments to enhance knowledge of geophysical plasma processes that will find use throughout plasma physics and aeronomy. The multidisciplinary nature of this work has established collaborations with plasma physicists, modelers, and space weather scientists. This research provided an excellent vehicle for undergraduate/graduate student & post doc participation in the CEDAR community and has added valuable new techniques and systems viewpoints to the CEDAR: The New Dimension paradigm. Results have been and will continue to published and presented in meetings and conferences. Several publications and at least one PhD thesis to come will acknowledge support under this grant.
